Dear Juliann Redmond Reynolds:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the Division of Child Welfare Licensing area manager,
Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-6992.

License Status: Regular

Capacity: 30
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
9/13/2023 Onsite Inspection Special Investigation Initiation
9/13/2023 Face to Face Interviews
10/11/2023 Face to Face Interviews
10/20/2023 Telephone Call Interviews
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following: (c)
Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety, and
supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation A youth escaped the secure facility on 9/9/23 by climbing the
fence to get to the roof and went down on the side of the building.
Investigation On 09/13/2023 an in-person meeting was held with the Chief
Administrator (CA) at Bay Couty Juvenile Home. CA confirmed
Youth A had escaped from the facility and as of today had not
been located. CA denied any knowledge the youth had expressed
a plan to escape from the secure facility and confirmed the legal
guardian and law enforcement had been notified. A tour of the
area outside where the youth was located prior to the escape was
completed. It was noted there were no open areas of the fencing,
barbed wire was around the entire fencing area and the fencing
was covered with anti-climb mesh. CA advised she was not
present at the time of the escape and could not provide any
firsthand account of what occurred.
On 09/13/2023 an in-person meeting was held with the
Complainant. No additional concerns were noted.
On 10/11/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2 at Bay
County Juvenile Home. Staff 2 is a youth development worker
and works 2nd shift; which is from 2pm to 10pm. She reported she
and two other staff were outside with most of the youth in the
program and they were preparing to go back in the building. She
stated she was focused on the group of youth that were in front of
her that were lining up. She noticed that the group of youth all
begin to look the other way at the same time and then started to
move into that direction. She saw Youth A climbing the fence and
then he jumped onto the roof. She then began to work at
regaining control of the remaining youth and requested that they
sit down and be silent. The youth were brought into the gym,
shoes were removed and then they all were taken to their rooms
for lockdown. Staff 2 reported that she feels that staff were
providing proper supervision and taking actions consistent with
their policy to maintain line of sight at all times. She further denied
any knowledge of Youth A sharing a plan to escape from the
facility.
On 10/11/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 3 at Bay
County Juvenile Home. She is a youth development worker and
works 2nd shift. She confirmed that she was working on the date of
the escape during 2nd shift. Staff 3 reported being outside for
recreation. She recalled nothing unusual going on. The staff
called for the youth to prepare to line up and return inside at
around 4:30pm. A basketball that needed to be returned inside
was in another area and Youth A went toward the area to get the
ball. She recalled hearing Staff 1 tell Youth A to get in line and
2

she saw Youth A point to something in the garden area. Staff 1
redirected Youth A and told him to leave it there and get in line.
Staff 3 said Youth A dropped the ball and started running. Staff 3
went to the area near the side of the building and saw Youth A
halfway up the fence. She reported Staff 3 was right near the
area, but could not pull the youth off the fence for fear of hurting
him. Staff 3 denied she or other staff failed to maintain line of
sight and denied Youth A ever made threats of a plan to escape.
Staff 3 reported since his return, Youth A continues to threaten to
escape again.
On 10/11/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth A at
Bay County Juvenile Home. Youth A stated the facility is kind of
secure, but “not really”. When asked, he was unable to give
examples or reasons why he believed the facility to not be secure.
Youth A denied he advised staff or any youth at the facility of his
intention to AWOL. He stated he was not sure what he was
thinking and was feeling really anxious. Youth A stated it was an
impulsive decision and he was not planning to run. He reported
playing around with the ball, acting like he needed to pick up
something and then “booked” to the fence. He stated staff were
within 10 feet of him and providing good supervision, but he was
just too fast for them. He crawled the fence, jumped on the roof
and then ran. Youth A reported he tried to escape again on
10/4/23 or 10/5/23. He was in the gym and climbed on the
volleyball stand and basketball hoop in an attempt to reach the
window but did not have any success. Youth A reported he is no
longer allowed to go into the gym for recreation as a part of his
safety plan. He denied having any plans to attempt an escape
right now.
On 10/11/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth B at
Bay County Juvenile Home. Youth B stated they were all
preparing to come back in from outside and he saw Youth A was
trying to grab a basketball and then he then jumped the fence and
ran. Youth B denied Youth A told him that he planned to escape
and feels that the staff were providing proper supervision.
On 10/11/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth C at
Bay County Juvenile Home. Youth C confirmed he was outside
when Youth A escaped. He reported when it was time to come in
from outside, Youth A pointed at a ball and was then seen
running. He jumped the fence and then proceeded to run. He
reported all the youth were moved back inside and placed on
lockdown. Youth C reported Youth A told Youth B and Youth D
that he was planning to escape. He denied Youth A told any staff
3

of his plan to escape. Youth C indicated staff were outside, and
he feels they were providing good supervision.
On 10/11/2023 an in-person interview was held with Youth D at
Bay County Juvenile Home. Youth D reported Youth A told him
he planned to escape and also stated he told “several staff”.
Youth D could not recall which staff were told, but thinks it was a
female staff. He stated when they were outside, Youth A snuck
over by the garden and then staff noticed that one youth was
missing. He stated he could hear the fence shaking and see
Youth A climbing the fence. He was successful in climbing the
fence and jumped on the roof and then ran. Youth D stated all the
youth were then taken back inside and placed on lock down.
Youth D reported that staff does a pretty good job supervising the
youth and follow policy.
On 10/20/2023 a telephone interview was held with Staff 1. He
reported being a youth development worker at Bay County
Juvenile Home and works 2nd Shift. He was present the day that
Youth A escaped. He denied knowledge that Youth A was
planning to escape and reported always following policy relative to
line of sight with youth. Staff 1 reported being outside and
preparing for all youth to return in the building when Youth A
began to act as if he needed to go to another area to pick up a ball
or return a ball. Staff 1 stated he noticed Youth A began to run
and was very quickly up the fence (with the no climb mesh) and
on to the roof of the building. Staff 1 reported he was quickly near
the youth while climbing the fence, but refrained from grabbing the
youth by the leg or foot as he did not want to injure him. Staff 1
reported he assisted the other staff with getting all the remaining
youth back into the building and followed all policy requirements
relative to an AWOL or escaped youth. Staff 1 further reported
additional oversight and monitoring has been implemented relative
to Youth A to ensure he does not attempt to escape again.
Documents Reviewed
Bay County Juvenile Home Incident Report #002007-
Documented that on 09/09/2023 Youth A did not line up,
disobeyed the orders of staff, climbed the fence, jumped on the
roof and then escaped. The report also indicated actions taken by
staff after the escape.
Safety Plan for Youth A – Safety plan indicated increased
monitoring for Youth A and also prohibited him from going outside
and in the gym. Alternative indoor recreation activities will be
4

provided for youth (i,e. connect four, cards and drawing) until he is
no longer assessed as an escape risk.
Bay County Juvenile Home Policy and Procedure Supervision
Policy - Policy indicated to ensure youth and public safety, youth
will never be left unattended in any areas inside or outside the
facility while in the care of the Bay County Juvenile Home.
Intensive staff supervision is intended to promote a positive
professional relationship between staff and youth as the primary
means of control. The exception is youth who are in their sleeping
rooms. In this case staff will complete the appropriate room
checks. Youth Development Workers are not to leave a situation
of directly supervising youth unless there is proper coverage of
supervising youth and Youth Development Workers shall keep line
of site for all youth or the group of youth they are responsible
to directly monitor when youth are not in their sleeping rooms.
Bay County Juvenile Home Policy and Procedure Policy –
Escapes – Policy indicates in the event a youth attempts to
escape from the facility, every reasonable effort shall be made to
regain custody while the youth is on the facility of the grounds.
Staff shall not engage in acts that could endanger the safety or
well being of the youth, themselves or the staff. The staff member
discovering the escape shall notify the control center and the
supervisor of all known information.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, there was no evidence to
support non-compliance with licensing rule 4109-1(C). There was
no evidence to support that the agency failed to follow the
supervision policy as written.
Technical Assistance
Rule 136 (2) Residents shall be provided a variety of indoor
and outdoor recreational activities designed to meet the
residents’ needs. Agency needs to review licensing Rule 136
(2). Policy requires that youth are provided with both indoor and
outdoor recreation activities. In the event it is assessed that
outdoor recreation is not appropriate based on youth needs, a
variance needs to be submitted for review and approved prior to
removing access to outdoor recreation.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule R 400.4165 Secure facilities serving juvenile justice
Section youth; lockdowns.
Description (2) A secure facility serving juvenile justice youth that uses
lockdowns in which all residents are confined to their rooms shall
5

have a written policy that describes the procedures to be followed
and includes all of the following:
(a) Who may order a lockdown.
(b) Who is to implement the lockdown when it has been ordered.
(c) How the problem is to be contained.
(d) Procedures to be followed after the incident is resolved.
(e) Notification of the licensing authority within 24 hours after the
occurrence of a lockdown.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agencies lockdown policy does not meet all requirements of
the rule and agency failed to notify DCWL of occurrence of a
lockdown within 24 hours.
Investigation On 10/11/2023 an in-person interview was held with Staff 2 at Bay
County Juvenile Home. Staff 2 advised that after Youth A
escaped, the other youth were brought into the gym, shoes were
removed and then they all were taken to their rooms for lockdown.
On 11/17/2023 a telephone interview was held with CA. She
confirmed that the agency had placed the youth on lockdown after
escape and that the agency had notified the parents and the
referral source when Youth A escaped. A request was made for
copies of the documentation and lockdown policy for review.
Documents reviewed:
Bay County Juvenile Home Policy and Procedure - Security
and Control/Facility Security Threats: Policy indicated staff shall
lock down youth for safety and security in emergency situations.
1. In the event of an attempted suicide or medical emergency it may be
necessary to lock down youth so that the focus may be on the youth in
need of aid.
2. In the event of an escape or escape threat/attempt youth may be
locked down in order to prevent additional escapes and to determine if
the youth who are attempting escape may be apprehended safely.
3. In the event of destruction in the facility, youth may be locked down
for safety and security. This lock down is to allow staff to clean up the
unsafe area or secure the unsafe area.
4. All lockdowns are to only last for the time of emergency and
subsequent tasks that need to be completed to ensure all is clear.
5. The Juvenile Home Director shall be notified as soon as possible after
a lockdown. The Director or designee shall notify the parents,
appropriate referral source and the Bureau of Child and Adult Licensing.
09/09/2023 Resident Daily Monitoring Log – Log documented that
interval checks are completed every 15 minutes while youth are in their
rooms. The log also documented that youth went into lockup at 4:15pm
6

and came out of lockup at 4:28pm. No additional information was
contained in the monitoring log.
Analysis The facility is found to be in noncompliance with licensing rule
400.4165 (2) as no notification was made to the licensing
consultant within 24 hours to advise that the agency was or had
been on lockdown. In addition, review of the Security
Control/Facility Security Threats policy that addressed lockdown
procedures failed to indicate that agency staff will make
notifications within 24 hours, did not include the requirement to
indicate who may order a lockdown, who may implement the
lockdown once ordered, how the problem is to be contained and
procedures for resolution.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
